awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Controlled Coating via Charged Droplet Impact and Deposition on Dielectric and Conducting Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Many products used by consumers and industry are coated with layers of materials to prevent corrosion or to provide specialized surface properties.  A common way to apply a coating is to spray a liquid onto the surface.  The effectiveness and resilience of the coating often depends on intricate details of how the liquid drops that impact the surface bounce, splash, and spread over the surface to form the coating.  Despite decades of research and practice, the fundamentals of coating processes, especially on products and machines with complex shapes, are not fully understood.  This GOALI project is a joint effort between the University of Illinois - Chicago (UIC) and the Spraying Systems Company to conduct experiments and develop numerical simulations that will determine whether coating processes can be improved by applying an electric field to control details of drop dynamics as the drops impact the surface.  The results of fundamental studies conducted at UIC will be used to develop spraying protocols that will be tested at Spraying Systems under industrially relevant conditions.  The research team at UIC and representatives from Spraying Systems will also conduct a series of outreach activities to engage students at all academic levels, especially those from underrepresented groups, in the research and related demonstrations.

The goal of this GOALI project is to investigate drop dynamics in the presence of an electric field to manipulate spray coating processes. The project will focus on droplet impact, deposition, and spreading on substrates attached to electrodes that generate an electric field.  Experiments will be conducted to analyze droplet impact and spreading on dielectric and conducting surfaces to evaluate the droplet's shape and spreading difference.  The influence of the morphology of the surface on droplet processes will be evaluated.  Phase-field modeling of droplet impact onto dielectric and conducting surfaces will be carried out, using ab initio density function theory calculations to obtain surface binding energies.  The results will be used to develops spraying protocols that will be tested in practice at Spraying Systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigates novel approaches for enhancing quality and performance of coating and painting with processes that involve impact of liquid drops on solid surfaces. The research is conducted in collaboration with Spraying Systems Co. (SSCo) to facilitate the transition of the results to market. This follows a previous project that investigated methods for increasing the efficiency and quality of spray formation by charging the liquid and has led to the development of electrostatic spraying devices by SSCo, which are now available commercially. The two primary goals of the current project are to (i) increase the fundamental understanding of the mechanisms of drop impact and spreading on a solid surface, and (ii) use the electric field to control drop spreading and prevent it from bouncing off the surface. By controlling the drop spreading, more uniform and consistent coating and painting are achieved. This is particularly important for coating surfaces with complex topologies where some parts are hard to reach with conventional sprays. By applying an electric field, charged drops can be guided to hidden parts of the surface, which are not easily reachable with conventional sprays.

A combination of experimental and computational methods augmented by customized AI algorithms is used to investigate the deposition of drops of different liquids on various surfaces. Computational research covers a broad range of scales from the atomic level to the macroscale model that simulates breakup of a liquid jet and the impact of the resulting drops on a surface. The experimental work has examined the impact of drops on dielectric surfaces, considering phenomena such as air bubble formation, electrically driven fingering, dielectrophoretic stretching of silicone oil drops, the evolution and shape of two-dimensional Stokesian drops, and drop impact on wood surfaces. Experiments have revealed that an applied electric field significantly affects the spreading of epoxy resin and hardener on polypropylene, increasing wetted areas, while having minimal impact on balsa wood due to different ion concentrations and surface properties. The simulation results have provided further details revealing that air can be trapped under the liquid drop during the initial impact as well as during the retraction phase due to the closure of the liquid layer above a cavity. It is found that the drop diameter and the impact velocity play significant roles in the air entrapment phenomena. The probability of air bubble formation is higher at lower impact velocity and for larger droplet size.

The results of the macroscale simulations along with direct experimental measurements were used to develop an AI model that predicts formation of air bubbles which could be detrimental to the quality of the coating or painting. This model accurately predicts the effect of drop diameter and impact velocity on air entrapment under liquid drops, helping to enhance the precision of deposition.

Several students were involved in this project and received widespread training in advanced computational and experimental techniques. The results were published through journals and conferences and were integrated in PIs’ courses.
